messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Culture is how people live.  
Differences are when things are not the same.  
It helps to know that people expect different things.  
This idea helps us avoid misunderstandings.  
But wrong ideas about people can hurt our work with others.  
Culture in each country can shape how we act.  
Culture can shape how we think.  
Where we live also affects how we act.  
Our groups of friends also affect how we act.  
Being a boy or a girl also makes a difference.  
The way a company works also affects us.  
Our own experiences also affect us.  
We should keep these ideas in mind.  
But we must not group all people from one country.
Feedback received: Grade 2/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. FAIL: Fidelity Failure. Suggestion: Restore essential concepts such as "corporate culture" and "individual experiences". Use precise terms from the original. Ensure the summary retains the full range of influences rather than focusing narrowly on national culture.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Culture means how people live and act.  
Differences are when things are not the same.  
It helps us to know these differences.  
It helps us avoid misunderstandings.  
But wrong ideas about people can hurt our work.  
Culture in each country shapes how we act.  
Culture in each country shapes how we think.  
Where we live also affects how we act.  
Our groups of friends also affect how we act.  
Our age makes a difference.  
Our gender makes a difference.  
Corporate culture (how a company works) also affects us.  
Our individual experiences also affect us.  
We should keep these ideas in mind.  
But we must not group all people from one country.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Culture is how people live and act.  
Difference means when things are not the same.  
Knowing possible differences helps us avoid cases of miscommunication.  
A stereotype is a wrong idea about a group of people.  
Stereotypes about cultures can hurt business relationships.  
Culture in each country shapes how we act and think.  
Where we live also affects how we act and think.  
The groups we join affect how we act and think.  
Our age affects how we act and think.  
Being a man or a woman affects how we act and think.  
Company culture is how a company works.  
It also affects how we act and think.  
Our individual experiences affect how we act and think.  
Keep these ideas in mind.  
But do not think all people in one country are the same.
Feedback received: Grade 2/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6329 is too low. The simplified sentences lose the original’s emphasis on avoiding pigeonholing and remembering multiple influences beyond national culture. FAIL: Fidelity Failure. The BERTScore of 0.8478 is below the required 0.90. Key phrases like “pigeonhole the individuals of an entire nation” and “corporate culture” were replaced with overly generic statements, stripping important nuance. Suggestion: Restore the warning against pigeonholing. Include the list of influences (region, community, age, gender, corporate culture, experiences) in one cohesive sentence. Use more of the original key terms to preserve meaning and improve fidelity.

Differences means when things are not the same.

A stereotype is a wrong idea about a group of people.  
Cultural stereotypes can hurt good business relationships.  
Culture in each country shapes how we act and think.

Do not use stereotypes to pigeonhole individuals of a whole nation.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: What is culture?  
Culture is how people live and think.  

What are differences?  
Differences are ways things are not the same.  

Knowing differences in expectations and behaviour helps us avoid misunderstandings.  
Wrong ideas about culture harm business relationships.  

National culture shapes how we behave and think.  
Our region shapes how we behave and think.  
Our community shapes how we behave and think.  
Our age shapes how we behave and think.  
Men can behave and think in one way.  
Women can behave and think in a different way.  
Company culture and our own experiences shape how we behave and think.  

We keep this knowledge at the back of our minds.  
We must avoid thinking all people in a country are the same.
Feedback received: Grade 2/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6685 is too low. The BERTScore of 0.851 is below the required 0.90.
- The concept of "cases of miscommunication" was lost; the text only says "misunderstandings".
- The warning about "cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships" was reduced to "wrong ideas about culture harm business relationships" without matching nuance.
- The original grouped "age and gender" together; the output splits men and women into separate unsourced claims, adding unsupported binary statements.
- Key phrase "avoid cases of miscommunication" was changed to "avoid misunderstandings," reducing fidelity.
- The output omits the instruction to keep knowledge "at the back of our minds rather than pigeonholing"; it only says "We keep this knowledge at the back of our minds".
Suggestion: Reintroduce the exact phrase "cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships." 
Suggestion: Merge gender into one item as "age and gender" instead of separate men/women statements.
Suggestion: Use the phrase "avoid cases of miscommunication" to match the original wording and restore key detail.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: What is culture?
Culture is how people live and think.

What are differences?
Differences are ways things are not the same.

We know what people want.
This helps us avoid cases of miscommunication.
We know how people behave.
This helps us avoid cases of miscommunication.

Cultural stereotypes can be detrimental to building good business relationships.

National culture shapes how we behave and think.
Our region shapes how we behave and think.
Our community shapes how we behave and think.
Our age and gender shape how we behave and think.
Our company culture shapes how we behave and think.
Our own life shapes how we behave and think.

We keep this knowledge at the back of our minds.
We must not use it to pigeonhole all people in a country.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.631 is too low. The writer’s output changes “an increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations” to “We know what people want,” which shifts from awareness and nuance to unjustified certainty. It also adds new definitions (“What is culture?” and “What are differences?”) that were not in the original and dilute the core message. Suggestion: Restore the phrase “increased awareness of the possible differences in expectations,” remove the added dictionary-style definitions, and maintain the original nuance about avoiding and not relying on stereotypes.
